thread.section_title: Business News, Economy, Finance & ASX Market News
thread.title: 'Dangerous game' picking RBA's next move

title: 'Dangerous game' picking RBA's next move
text:
Even those who still expect the RBA to keep rates on hold for the rest of the year have started qualifying their analysis. Photo: Nicholas Rider
The Australian dollar has been caught up in a heavy commodity currency sell-off, testing a fresh six-year low, but whether the mood for further stimulus motivates the Reserve Bank of Australia to cut rates again is not so clear.
Currencies traded emphatically on Wednesday night in a session dominated by headlines from US Federal Reserve chairwoman Janet Yellen's congressional testimony, more eurozone rumblings and a rate cut in Canada that was seen as only a 50-50 chance heading into the meeting.
A shock outcome from New Zealand's dairy auction, where prices fell 10 per cent, sealed a savage session for the New Zealand dollar too.
A 10 per cent drop in prices at New Zealand's online dairy auction derailed the Kiwi. Photo: Louie Douvis
The Australian currency tumbled to US73.67Â¢ on Thursday.
Advertisement "It's not obvious that markets are fully prepared for what's going on," said ANZ's foreign exchange strategist Richard Yetsenga. "We haven't had a Fed tightening cycle for more than 10 years and the pressure for easing elsewhere is still intense."
Mr Yetsenga said he did not get the sense that people trading the market genuinely expect higher rates from the Fed this year, even though the central bank's forecasts point to a rate rise. "I think they've just been marking time and not really believing."
Dr Yellen used her appearance before Congress to repeat that the Fed intends to raise rates this year, and perhaps as soon as September, if the economic data supports "lift-off". The Fed chairwoman has been consistent in her communications this year but markets have seen the chaos created by the Greek rescue as giving the Fed further cause to wait.
That may not be the case.
"The fact she kept up her rhetoric last night in such a formal setting" underscored the Fed's seriousness, Mr Yetsenga said.
A US dollar rally could step up the currency relief for the Reserve Bank of Australia at a time when the grinding rout in hard and soft commodities is suppressing commodity currencies.
Dino Spinelli, UBS head of foreign exchange sales in Australia and New Zealand, observed how the currency was caught in a "downdraft" as commodity-centric economies shifted course. The Reserve Bank of New Zealand started reversing its tightening cycle with June's rate cut; only months ago the NZ dollar was headed for Australian dollar parity.
"The turn of events in the last month to six weeks from the central banks in the commodity sector has created this heightened volatility," Mr Spinelli said.
"The RBA have been reluctant cutters as we're aware. There's been a period over 2015 when a lot of their peers in Asia have all been easing, and the markets like to think, 'Well, their peers are easing in Asia, surely they're going to be enthused and ease as well'.
"To think about what Canada did last night and assume the RBA's likely to cut in the next few months because of that is a dangerous game," he said. "They're still reluctant cutters, they really are.
"It's an argument for them to wait and see."
With a US rate rise potentially two months away, that could be a reason for the RBA to stay on the sidelines, Mr Spinelli said.
"We're very close and closer than we have been for last two years that the Fed might do something. That's another argument for not cutting rates."
On Thursday, financial markets were pricing in a more than 60 per cent chance of one-quarter of a percentage point rate reduction to 1.75 per cent by the end of 2015.
National Australian Bank currency strategist Emma Lawson said the NZ dollar bore the brunt of market turmoil on the dairy outcome "that was abysmal really".
"It just adds to what we already knew, there is pressure there on the terms of trade for Australia and New Zealand," Ms Lawson said.
She said the foreign exchange market's response to the rate cut in Canada and the plunge in dairy prices was "fairly normal" because both situations delivered negative outcomes with somewhat of a degree of surprise.
